doc.field: Attempts to Mediate Dispute Over Prescription Drug Budget

Federal Health Minister Andrea Fischer and representatives from the insurance doctors association tried this evening to defuse the battle over the prescription drug budget. Fischer (Greens) called the meeting in Bonn on short notice in reaction to the threat by the physicians to counter the cuts in the drug and medication budget with an emergency plan. According to this plan, doctors would establish a waiting list for non-urgent medication if budget shortfalls are expected. Thyroid medication as well as treatments for fungal infections and diarrhea were named as examples. Health Minister Fischer declared that she would issue a directive banning this emergency plan if necessary. She said a waiting list for patients was unacceptable.
Greens "Realists" Present Agenda

Several prominent Greens politicians have called for a new environment policy and for closer cooperation with businesses. The "Realists," including the spokesperson for the executive committee Gunda Roestel, presented a 10-point agenda which called for reinstating the environment as the focal point of political action. This was not to be taken as criticism of Environment Minister Juergen Trittin, rather as an appeal to the entire party for a reorientation. In the future, the Greens want to have ecology seen as a part of modernization. A spokesperson for the Federation [of German Industry] said that it was a welcome insight that environmental protection must be carried out in a manner that was also to some extent compatible with business.
Unions Reject Solidarity with CDU/CSU

Leading unions have rejected standing shoulder-to-shoulder with the CDU/CSU against the government's plans for pension policies. In response to offers of this nature from the CDU/CSU parliamentary group's vice chairman Juergen Ruettgers, the German Federation of Trade Unions (DGB) said they would not let themselves be appropriated by any party.
Discussion on Role of Armed Forces

The military is not getting a break during the parliamentary summer break. In a radio interview, SPD military expert Helmut Wieczorek renewed his call to rethink the constitutional limitations on deployment of the armed forces to purely military missions. It was not against the constitution for the armed forces occasionally to assist in police operations, for example in securing the border or combating smuggling rings. The debate was triggered by an article in the "Bild" newspaper. The article referred to a classified speech manuscript by Inspector General Hans-Peter von Kirchbach, according to which the armed forces should prepare itself for new areas of engagement in view of the decreasing threats of danger from the outside. Kirchbach himself vehemently denied that the armed forces would be deployed for domestic security in the future.
Charite Demands Compensation

After a camera man's death of yellow fever, Berlin Charite wants to have 400,000 DM reimbursed by the Berlin Senate. The hospital administration said that since infectious diseases come under the purview of the state, the loss of income from an entire ward emptied by the quarantine should be reimbursed.
Bavarian Crime Statistics

Bavaria is the safest state according to the crime statistics published today by the Free State of Bavaria. Only five crimes are committed per 100 inhabitants - the national average is eight. In the first six months of the year, the number of crimes fell by 1.2 percent to 325,000. State Interior Secretary Regensburger said he was satisfied, "People always ask what the reason could be that things are better in Bavaria than in other states. I believe that we are on the right path when we do not tolerate lawlessness. Secondly, I think it is also an exceptional quality that we have that the relationship between the citizens and the police is for the most part a very good one." Thefts, at 37 percent, made up the largest portion of all crimes.
Court Rules Against Integration of Handicapped

The Administrative Court of the state of Saarland has denied the petition of a blind girl to attend a regular school. The girl must continue to attend - as previously decreed by the education authorities - the school for the blind and visually impaired in Lebach, Saarland. As grounds for the decision the court cited the lack of special education curriculum and support in a regular elementary school class.
Bitter Balance

The July salary statement brought tears to the eyes of a cleaning lady at the Bavarian state assembly: from her holiday bonus of 325 DM, only 3.48 DM was left after deductions. The Revenue Office kept 99 percent for taxes and social security contributions. The holiday money bumped the woman into a higher tax bracket, thus not much was left.
Eclipse Epilogue

Looking at the solar eclipse had consequences for a few fans of the natural phenomenon. At least two people suffered eye injuries. It was particularly bad for an 18-year-old Berlin man who lost 90 percent of his sight. A 15-year-old boy in Schwerin is threatened with permanent retina damage because he looked directly at the sun. There was no mass rush on hospitals, as was feared.
Steffi Graf Calls Press Conference for Tomorrow

Steffi Graf apparently intends to end the guessing game on her future in sports. The 30-year-old from Bruehl hastily called a press conference for tomorrow. This is the first time in her career that she has done so. There has been no word as of yet on the subject or the motivation, however after the conjecture of the past weeks, clarification is expected.
